biogHist.abstract: The Padbury Boys' Farm School was run by the Anglican Orphanages Committee as part of Swan Homes from 1946 to 1955, on land owned by the Anglican church in Stoneville. Boys were sent there to gain training and experience in farm work.
biogHist.p: The Padbury Boys' Farm School at Stoneville was part of the Swan Homes complex, established in 1946 to provide agricultural training to boys from Swan Homes. It was named in honour of two benefactors of Swan Homes: Mr Walter Padbury and his nephew, Matthew Padbury. Boys old enough to be 'trainees' were at first accepted to Padbury, but after 1948 'schoolboys' were also sent there. Boys cleared the land, erected buildings, worked on the farm, and helped put out bush-fires in the community.
School-age boys attended the Mt Helena Area School.
In 1955, the Padbury Boys' Farm School was closed, for financial reasons.
The Padbury Boys' Farm School was mentioned in the Lost Innocents Report (2001) as an institution involved in the migration of children to Australia.

chronItem.event: Location - Padbury Boys' Farm School was situated on 360 acres of land at Stoneville

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )

descriptiveNote.p: 'Hillston - Minutes of the Diocesan Trustees [excerpt]' documents the transfer of the site formerly occupied by Padbury Farm School from the Anglican Church to the State of Western Australia.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Ken Pound interviewed by Gwenda Davey in the Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants oral history project (2010)
Child and Youth Migration to Western Australia (1913 - 1968)
Perth Protestant Orphanage / Perth Anglican Orphanages, State Library of Western Australia (1872 - 1955)

descriptiveNote.p: After Padbury Boys' Farm School closed, its buildings and grounds were used for the Anglican Farm School, Stoneville.
Padbury Boys' Farm School operated as a branch of Swan Homes.
Children and young people from Padbury Boys' Farm School came to the Seaside House at Coogee for annual summer holidays.

archref.repository: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives
archref.abstract: 'Coogee Home [II]' is a digital copy of an item held in the Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives. Written on the back of the image are the words: 'Barbeque area at Coogee - note new wing - bathroom and laundry. 9/33. Holidays - Coogee.' From 1931 to 1959 the children from Swan Boys' Orphanage (to 1942) and Perth Girls' Orphanage (to 1942), and then the Swan Homes (from 1943) and Padbury Boys' Farm School (from 1946), came to Coogee for an annual summer holiday. From 1946, there were children living at the Home all year and in 1948 a new ablution block and laundry had been built, giving an approximate date for this image.
archref.note: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives.

archref.repository: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives
archref.abstract: 'Coogee Home [I]' is a digital copy of an item held in the Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives. Written on the back of the image are the words: 'Our Seaside Home. Coogee. 9/42. Holidays - Coogee.' From 1931 to 1959 the children from Swan Boys' Orphanage (to 1942) and Perth Girls' Orphanage (to 1942), and then the Swan Homes (from 1943) and Padbury Boys' Farm School (from 1946), came to Coogee for an annual summer holiday. From 1946, there were children living at the Home all year.
archref.note: Anglican Diocese of Perth, Western Australia, Archives.

archref.abstract: This is a file held online by the National Archives of Australia. It has draft reports on the Australian institutions which took unaccompanied British child migrants after World War Two.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The Noisy Mansions : the story of Swanleigh 1868-1971

archref.unittitle: The Noisy Mansions : the story of Swanleigh 1868-1971
archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of The Noisy Mansions, which is a history of the Western Australian Anglican orphanage which became Swan Homes and finally Swanleigh. The Noisy Mansions was written by A. Roy Peterkin, the long-standing Director of the Home.
archref.note: Perth Diocesan Trustees, Anglican Church of Australia.
